Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136 Recreational activities, equipment, and
Section supplies; swimming restriction.
Description (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation All incidents occurred between August and the first week in
October. During this time frame, the children have not been
allowed to go outside due to a gate being out of code. The gate
leads directly to the girl’s dorms and the facility management is
aware of the need for repair and have instructed staff not to allow
the male children outside. It is believed this contributed to the
children becoming depressed and stir crazy.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2023, and reported since the facility opened the gate has
never worked so male youth have never been allowed outside
for recreation.
Director, Nurse, Supervisor and Assistant Facility
Administrator (AFA) were interviewed face to face separately,
at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. All individuals reported male youth have not been
outside since the facility opened due to issues with the gate not
keeping the male youth separated from the female youth.
2

Youth A and Youth B were interviewed face to face,
separately, at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. They both reported not being allowed
outside because the gate was broken. Both youth stated they
have “rec” time daily in the gym.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker 2 who was with Youth D at
his home. Youth D reported never going outside during his three
weeks stay at the facility because the gate was broken. Youth D
stated he played basketball in the gym.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E reported
never going outside at the facility because the gate was broken.
Youth E stated “rec” time was in the gym playing basketball and
other activities.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported
the gate has been broken since the facility opened so male youth
have not been allowed outside.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as youth have not been
provided any outside recreational opportunities since the facility
opened. Currently the outside recreation area would allow the
male youth to come within sight and sound of the female youth at
the facility so male youth have not been allowed outside.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
Section (2) Meals shall be of sufficient quantity to meet the nutritional
Description allowances recommended by USDA
guidelines:(www.healthierus.gov/dietaryguidelines)
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The children are denied "good nutrition."
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2023, and reported youth are not provided enough food and
will refuse to eat meals because they are not nutritious.
Complainant stated Youth B was still hungry after a meal and AFA
brought him a sandwich. Complainant reported having concerns
with the Hillbilly bread, tomato soup and youth only being allowed
one piece of cheese on a sandwich. Complainant stated she did
not feel the food was healthy enough for the youth.
3

Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Director reported youth are provided three meals daily and
multiple snacks. Director denied being aware of any youth not
receiving a meal or not getting enough food. Director stated he
works with the kitchen manager on the menu to ensure there are
fruits, vegetables, protein and one starch for every meal. Director
reported the facility is moving to make more homemade meals.
Director reported he is a French trained cook and is
knowledgeable of planning nutritious meals.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse denied
being aware of any youth not being provided a meal or getting
enough to eat. Nurse stated she did not have any concerns with
the food the youth are provided, and the meals meet the
nutritional value required for the youth. Nurse described fruit
being offered 24 hours a day and if a youth is still hungry, they are
provided a sandwich or leftovers.
Supervisor and Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) were
interviewed face to face separately, at the facility on October
11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. They both
denied being aware of any youth not being provided a meal or
getting enough to eat. Supervisor and AFA both described youths
being provided a sandwich, leftovers, or a snack if the youth is still
hungry. Supervisor stated the meals are a good mix of food and
nutritious. AFA described meats, vegetables and fruits being
provided at every meal.
Youth A and Youth B were interviewed face to face,
separately, at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. They both reported always getting enough
food and it being “good.” Both youth denied ever missing a meal.
Youth A described some of the meals as cereal, bagels, cream
cheese, tacos, fruits, and vegetables. Youth A stated if he was
still hungry after a meal, he would get seconds. Youth B reported
fruits and snacks are always available.
Kitchen Manager was interviewed face to face at the facility
on October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Kitchen Manager denied any meals being missed or running out of
food for meals. Kitchen manager stated she works with Director
to develop a menu and follow the nutrition requirements. Kitchen
manager reported she does not have any concerns with the menu
and what is being served to the youth.
4

Youth C was interviewed face to face at Mesick High School
on October 12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Youth C stated he did not eat when he was at the facility because
the food looked disgusting. Youth C reported he arrived at the
facility around 4pm and left approximately three hours later.
Youth C could not recall what food was being provided that he
thought looked disgusting. Youth C stated he could not recall
much of his time at the facility because he was only there a short
period of time.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker 2 who was with Youth D at
his home. Youth D described the food being “good.” Youth D
denied ever being hungry or not getting a meal. Youth D
described some of his favorite foods at the facility as blueberry
muffins, spaghetti, milk, garlic bread, pasta, and pie. Youth D
stated there were always snacks available.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E
described the food as good, always getting three meals a day as
well as snacks. Youth E stated he always got enough food to eat
and was not aware of any youth who missed meals or did not get
enough food. Youth E reported eating bananas, apples, fruits,
snacks, and pasta.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 denied
having any concerns with the food youth are provided or youth not
getting enough food. Staff 1 stated the food is good and he often
eats it too.
Documents Reviewed
• September and October 2023 menus show an assortment
of nutritional meals being provided. Meals list fruits,
vegetables, proteins, and dessert being provided.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as staff and youth reported
having enough to eat and meals that had fruits, vegetables, and a
protein. None of the youth interviewed reported not having
enough food or snacks provided to them.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Some of the children go without with medications for two to four
days causing a negative reaction. One youth has contemplated
suicide and attempted to break out of the facility. Another youth
was declining mentally in the facility; he was put on medication
that was not prescribed.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2023, and reported Youth B went several days without
medication because the facility ran out of the medication.
Complainant stated Youth E was given a medication he was not
prescribed. Complainant reported Youth B and Youth E reported
this information to Complainant. Complainant denied ever seeing
the medication given to Youth B and Youth E or dispensing
medication.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse reported
Youth E’s medication was picked up at a different pharmacy, so
the pill looked different. Nurse stated Youth E kept saying it was a
different medication even though it was explained to him it was the
same medication just a different color pill.
Nurse reported Youth B missed two medications on September
24, 2023, because he ran out of the medication. Nurse stated
Youth B’s doctor retired and there was no one to prescribe the
medication. Nurse described reaching out to the facility’s
psychiatrist to schedule an appointment for Youth B and the
psychiatrist was able to prescribe Youth B’s medication, but Youth
B missed one evening dose of two medications. Nurse reported
this is the only youth that has run out of medication while at the
facility. Nurse denied Youth A running out of one medication.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
A reported not getting one of his medications in August or
September for a couple of days because the facility ran out of the
medication. Youth A stated this was the only time that occurred.
Youth A denied being given any medication he was not
prescribed.
6

Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Supervisor stated she is trained to dispense medication to youth.
Supervisor reported she signed the Medication Administration
Report, MAR, for Youth B on accident when the medication was
not given. Supervisor stated she should have used white out to
correct her error. Supervisor stated if a youth is out of medication
Nurse should be notified. Supervisor reported Nurse prepares the
medications in a bubble pack and the medications are listed at the
top of the bubble pack. Supervisor stated if a youth were to run
out of medication Nurse would let staff know.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
B described running out of two medications when he was first
placed at the facility. Youth B stated he did not have the
medications for two days and it was the only time his medication
ran out. Youth B denied being given any medication he was not
prescribed.
Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) was interviewed face
to face at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. AFA reported some youth come into the
facility without enough medications, so Nurse must make a lot of
phone calls to make arrangements to get the medications. AFA
stated if a youth does not get a medication for whatever reason
staff write an incident report.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker 2 who was with Youth D at
his home. Youth D reported he received his medications daily
and on time. Youth D denied every being given the wrong
medication.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E reported
he always received his mediation at the facility. Youth E denied
ever getting the wrong medication. Youth E stated he heard
Youth B’s medication got “messed up” but the facility figured it out.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 denied
youth ever not getting their medication. Staff 1 stated Youth E
once said he was not being given the correct pill, so Nurse was
asked and she explained the pill was a different color but the
7

same medication. Staff 1 reported he was not aware Youth B
ever ran out of medication.
Documents Reviewed
• Youth A’s September MAR: September 16 square blank,
no incident report indicating why square did not have any
initials or what happened with the medication.
• Youth B’s September MAR: September 24 had
Supervisor’s initials for two medications the Nurse reported
the facility ran out of. No incident report for situation.
• Youth B’s October MAR: October 9 square blank for one
medication, no incident report indication why square did not
have any initials or what happened with the medication.
• Youth E’s September MAR: September 18 and September
20 squares blank, no incident reports indicating why
squares did not have any initials or what happened with the
medications.
• Osceola Youth Center Administration of Medication Policy:
Staff administering the medication shall note and initial on
the MAR the medications that were administered. The
following codes shall be used: (a) D/C - Discontinued order
(b) R - Youth refused medication (c) O - Omitted, with
explanation on the back of the MAR (d) X – Do not give.
Medication errors shall be documented and investigated
promptly by the nurse on duty and Medical Services
Manager or designee. The Medication Error Report to
include a root cause analysis shall be completed,
forwarded and incident brought to attention of Health
Services Administrator or designee by on-site staff prior to
end of shift. The Medication Error Report shall not be filed
in youth’s Medical File, but kept in the Health Services file.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth B ran out of two
medications on September 24, yet Supervisor initialed the square
indicating the medications were given. MARs for Youth A, Youth
B, and Youth E had blank squares but no documentation
indicating why the squares were blank.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies ad procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
8

Allegation About a month ago, another youth was about to have a seizure, it
took 10 minutes for staff to assist, then staff called 911.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2023, and reported they had no further information.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse described
receiving a phone shortly after leaving the facility from AFA stating
Youth C was sitting at the end of his bed unresponsive to staff.
Nurse stated the phone call switched to FaceTime so she could
see Youth C. Nurse reported she instructed staff to call 911.
Nurse stated she told AFA and Supervisor to move Youth C to the
ground and place him on his side. Nurse stated while on
FaceTime Youth C tightened his stomach, started seizing and
threw up. Nurse reported Youth C did not have a history of
seizures, that nothing was noted in his medical intake paperwork.
Nurse stated when she returned to the facility Youth C was loaded
into the ambulance. Nurse reported she felt staff did what they
should have done for Youth C and acted appropriately.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Supervisor reported during shower time Youth C was sitting at the
end of his bed and something seemed off, he was not sitting
normal and would not answer when spoken to. Supervisor stated
she had introduced herself to Youth C approximately 15 minutes
prior to this this, because he had just arrived at the facility, and
Youth C talked to her and did not have any issues. Supervisor
reported she called AFA, who’s office is on the unit, and AFA
walked into Youth C’s room. Supervisor stated AFA came right
away to assist. Supervisor stated AFA and Supervisor continued
talking to Youth C, but he did not answer. Supervisor described
Youth C falling back onto his bed and Nurse immediately being
called on Zoom. Supervisor stated Nurse told them (Supervisor
and AFA) to call 911 and to move Youth C on the floor on his side.
Supervisor denied Youth C having a history of seizures.
Supervisor reported the ambulance arrived about ten minutes later
and transported Youth C to the hospital.
Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) was interviewed face
to face at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. AFA stated Staff 2 called out to her and
stated something was going on with Youth C, so AFA walked out
of her office, which is on the unit, to Youth C’s room to check on
him. AFA reported Youth C was sitting on his bed, not responding
when spoken to so AFA called Nurse right away. AFA described
9

911 being called next while Nurse directed staff to move Youth C
on the floor and place on his side. AFA reported Youth C stated
having seizure like activity and vomited. AFA stated the
ambulance arrived in about 10 minutes and when Nurse arrived
back at the facility Youth C was already loaded into the
ambulance. AFA stated it was a matter of seconds from when she
was called out to from when she walked into Youth C’s room to
check on him. AFA reported Nurse and 911 were called right
away.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
A described Youth C having a seizure, his first day at the facility,
and the ambulance coming to take Youth C to the hospital. Youth
A reported Supervisor and AFA were with Youth C the whole time.
Youth A stated Supervisor called 911 and the ambulance came
right away. Youth A reported Nurse came to the facility after the
ambulance. Youth A denied having any concerns with how staff
responded to Youth C.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
B reported he remembered Youth C having a seizure and going
home. Youth B stated he did not see what happened because he
does not pay attention to that kind of stuff and probably went into
his room away from the situation.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at Mesick High School
on October 12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Youth C reported he arrived at the facility around 4pm and left
approximately three hours later. Youth C stated he remembered
feeling cold suddenly then waking up at the Reed City Hospital,
falling back to sleep then waking up in Grand Rapids at the
hospital. Youth C stated he could not recall much of his time at
the facility because he was only there a short period of time.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker 2 who was with Youth D at
his home. Youth D reported not knowing what staff did about
Youth C’s seizure, but he believes staff handled it appropriately.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E
described hearing Youth C had a seizure, but Youth E was not at
the facility when it occurred.
10

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported
he was off the day Youth C had a seizure.
Documents Reviewed
• Incident Report for Youth C dated 09/05/23 at 6:59pm:
consistent with Supervisor and AFA’s interviews describing
Youth C’s movements, calling Nurse and 911.
• Youth C’s Face Sheet: No history of seizure activity noted.
• Initial Health Screen for Youth C dated 09/05/2023: No
history of seizure activity noted.
• Osceola Youth Center Episodic – First Aid and Emergency
Care Policy and Procedure: Health care or on-duty
administrative staff shall immediately contact the contract
or on-call medical staff, mental health professional or
dentist, as appropriate, report on the youth’s condition and
receive orders, if indicated.
Tour Observation:
A tour of Owl Unit occurred on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. The bedrooms for the youth are located in
the same hallway as AFA’s office. A person would be able to walk
between AFA’s office and Youth C’s bedroom in a few seconds.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Supervisor and AFA
responded timely and appropriately to Youth C’s medical
condition. The facility’s policy was followed with Nurse being
contacted by AFA and Nurse directing staff to call 911.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure
Section facilities; seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and
Description elimination.
(11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was suicidal and blacked out; during that time, he was
locked in his room. The staff knowingly ignore him and caused
him to be triggered.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2023, and reported Youth A would black out and destroy his
room. Complainant stated Youth A would be locked in his room
when this happened for up to three hours.
Nurse was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Nurse stated she
11

never heard of Youth A having a black out spell, destroying his
room, or being locked in his room.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker.
Supervisor stated youth are separated when one is escalated,
meaning the group is taken to a different space giving the youth
who is escalated a chance to calm down. Supervisor denied
youth being locked in their room and stated the facility is not
allowed to seclude. Supervisor denied Youth A ever being locked
in his room or destroy his room.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
A described going to his bedroom or a different area of the facility
if a youth is escalated. Youth A stated he has gone to his room to
calm down a few times because of his anger. Youth A stated the
door is locked but staff will let you out if you ask or if you must use
the bathroom. Youth A reported youth are locked in their
bedrooms at bedtime. Youth A denied blacking out in his room or
destroying it.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
October 11, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth
B described if a youth is escalated the group has to move to get
away from the youth that is escalated. Youth B denied staff ever
forcing youth into their rooms and not letting them out. Youth B
stated the only time youth are locked in their rooms is at bedtime
but if you need to use the bathroom staff will let you out. Youth B
stated the only youth he recalled destroying his room was Youth E
and it occurred at bedtime when youth were already in their rooms
for the night.
Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) was interviewed face
to face at the facility on October 11, 2023, in collaboration
with DHHS Worker. AFA stated staff will move the other youth
when one youth is escalated. AFA described the youth being
moved to the gym, day room or their rooms but youth are never
locked in their rooms. AFA denied Youth A ever being locked in
his room, blacking out and destroying his room. AFA stated she
was not working the night Youth E destroyed his room, but she
heard that situation occurred at bedtime when the youth were
already locked in their rooms.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on October 12, 2023,
in collaboration with DHHS Worker 2 who was with Youth D at
12

his home. Youth D described the only time being locked in his
room was at bedtime. Youth D denied being aware of any youth
being locked in their room.
Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E
described being locked in his room at bedtime but that was the
only time. Youth E stated youth could go to the room when they
wanted to and come out when they wanted to. Youth E denied
being aware of any youth locked in their room.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on October
19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 1 denied
any youth being locked in their room, other than at bedtime.
Documents Reviewed
• Clinical Note for Youth A dated 9/15/23: Describes Youth A
as having aggressive impulses but no suicidal tendencies
or blacking out episodes.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as interviews with youth and
staff do not indicate youth are being locked in their rooms other
than bedtime. All the youth interviewed reported being able to
enter and leave their bedroom when they ask staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(ii) Family time or any type of communications with family.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth's parental visit was cancelled due to youth being in a
restraint two days prior to scheduled visit.
Investigation Youth E was interviewed face to face at his home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth E stated a
visit with his mother was cancelled due to Youth E being in a
restraint. Youth E reported the visit only got cancelled one time.
Parent was interviewed face to face at her home on October
12, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Parent reported
she had a visit with Youth E scheduled for September 16, 2023, at
the facility. Parent stated on September 14 or September 15,
2023, a staff person from the facility called and said the visit was
13

cancelled because Youth E was in a restraint. Parent thought it
was AFA or Supervisor who called to cancel the visit, but she was
not certain what staff called. Parent stated communication was
always good with staff from the facility, but she did not think it was
right she would not be able to see her son, Youth E, because he
was in a restraint a couple of days prior to her visit. Parent
reported this was the only visit that was cancelled.
Director and AFA were interviewed face to face, separately, at
the facility on October 19, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. They both reported Youth E’s visit was cancelled with
his mother due to him being in a restraint. Director and AFA
believed visits could be cancelled due to a youth’s behavior
because the facility is a detention.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth E’s visit with his
mother was cancelled due to Youth E being in a restraint two days
prior to the scheduled visit. Director and AFA believed visits could
be cancelled due to the facility being a detention center.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
